ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Greatly developed understanding of Chinese culture and history. Learned an in-depth history of Chinese women and Chinese poetry. Learned the basics of calligraphy and Chinese visual art. Literary analysis, close reading, comparison, and critical thinking skills developed.

I gained a deeper understanding of both the history of China and the analysis of poetry in translation. My previous courses on China rarely discussed the role of women in Chinese society so this course was a breath of fresh air: Chinese womens poetry allowed us to investigate the rich history of feminism, and its intersections with political and other social developments, across the dynasties.
I learned so much about the Chinese literary canon! The canon was really not something I had much exposure to, and I was so delighted to learn about its central themes and motifs.
how to analyze literature and read primary sources
i learned a ton about womens literature in traditional china and just about chinese history in general!

I learned a lot about the women's poetry in ancient, dynastic China. We discussed more technical aspects like the poetic form and imagery as well as contextual factors like the environment and cultural traditions.
I learned so much about women in Chinese literary history. I also learned how to close read and move between the original Chinese poem and its various English translations.

I learned so much about women in traditional China. I learned about how feminism came about in China, and I learned how the words of Confucious were used by women in order to make their arguments. I also learned how to do a close reading of Chinese poetry and I learned different symbols in Chinese poetry.
I learned about gender roles in Ancient China and how they evolved throughout the dynasties.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was a wonderful course. Professor Chang is absolutely amazing. She lectured passionately while allowing space for students to jump in with our own thoughts and questions. I thought the lecture-discussion format was effective and the course content was well structured in chronological manner.

I dont really think there were weaknesses. Professor Chang was beloved by the class, and her syllabus was a wonderful introduction into the Chinese literary canon. I loved that the class was organized by theme; it made the pacing really great.
This class is so wonderfully taught. The discussions are very student-driven and Professor Chang knows so much about all of the topics.

there were so many poems assigned for each class yet very few discussed, so it was often difficult to do the readings since the load was so high yet it felt like we never talked about the majority of them. professor chang is the BEST though, shes so passionate and fun and it was such a joy to hear her talk about the content. she also gives very thorough and clear comments on the essays which is super helpful
strengths: the professor is extremely knowledgeable and helpful. the teaching team really encourages student participation as well.

Strengths: Really amazing professor who is extremely passionate about the subject. Interesting discussions led by TA.
Weaknesses: Sometimes the lectures went on for very long with little student engagement

Strengths: Professor Chang. She is absolutely wonderful. She is so brilliant and just so lovely. I greatly enjoyed learning with her. 

There are no weaknesses to this class. It was so well taught and it was such a joyful class because it is a topic that is not usually talked about.

The course material - women in literature in traditional China - is such a fascinating, niche topic. 

I wish that this course had been in person to facilitate more engaging discussions, but all things considered, the Zoom format worked well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The virtual format worked well; it was very engaging despite the limitations of virtual learning. 

Because of the lax attitude of the course, I think few students did the readings. For this reason, I would have preferred the addition of a weekly Canvas discussion post or comparable alternative. Live virtual discussion may have been more fruitful that way.

Again, the lecture-discussion format was effective in keeping students engaged throughout the semester. Sitting through an hour long lecture can be draining while having a Zoom discussion for over an hour can feel burdensome to many students. This class was a great balance between the two.
Once again, I feel like the class was great. Professor Chang made great use of the share-screen option to essentially show us slides.
honestly it was totally fine! the discussions i think would have been better in person but the lectures were great
I really wish the discussions could have been in person, but I am still glad I took this course.
Shortened final paper was very helpful. Low-stress discussions.
Professor Chang was really understanding and accomodating during this time and I am so grateful for that.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. This course was an outstanding introduction to the East Asian Languages and Literature major and to Chinese poetry and gender studies.
Yes! The course material is interesting (ties in feminism, East Asian Studies, comparative literature, love...) and Professor Chang teaches with unparalleled passion.

Definitely! I think its such a good way of understanding an entirely different tradition that bears fascinating similarities with the Western one that may be more familiar to students. The class is both fun and you learn SO much.
yes! wonderful class and professor

Yes! Although its a shame that Professor Chang wont be teaching this course next year, the course material was super interesting and it was refreshing to learn literature from a non-eurocentric point of view.
absolutely! it was really fun to read and talk about everything, i really learned so much about a topic i had literally zero knowledge of before.
Yes, I learned so many things about Chinese poetry that I never thought I would have had the opportunity to appreciate.
Yes x 10000000. Although sadly Prof. Chang will not be teaching this class again, it was so amazing and you really learn so much.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course. Even though Professor Chang is retiring, it is such incredibly interesting material.

I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in Asia or ancient literature. The class is accessible to all students as it is taught in English and there are no prerequisites, and I think both students who already know about this topic and those who are less familiar with women in ancient China will enjoy this course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: virtual lecture and seminar fusion
N/a
Virtual live lecture followed by seminar
the first half of each class was a virtual lecture and the second half was a seminar-style discussion
Live virtual lecture with TA-led discussion at the end of class.
None
N/A
Lecture + seminar
